Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Design documents are due soon and other teams are waiting for their technical input
Story: My phone buzzed at 2:13 a.m., jolting me awake. It was Sam, my closest friend, his name lighting up the screen. I answered, and immediately heard his shaky voice, thick with tears. He could barely get the words out—something terrible had happened in his family. I sat up, heart pounding, trying to listen, to be present, to offer the comfort he needed. But as he spoke, my mind kept drifting to the looming deadline. The design documents for the new feature were due in less than eight hours, and the other teams were waiting on my technical input. I knew they were counting on me to clarify the architecture, to answer questions that would unblock their work. I wanted to be there for Sam, to give him my full attention, but the weight of my responsibility at work pressed down on me. I felt torn, guilt gnawing at me from both sides, as I tried to balance the needs of my friend with the demands of my team.
